ACTION UNDER INTERNAL SECURITY ACT


    Order read for Resumption of Debate on Question (25th May, 1988),

    "That this House -

    (a) supports the firm action of the Government to prevent our country from being subverted whether by Marxists, communists, western powers or other foreign interest groups,

    (b) deplores, in view of recent disclosures, all foreign interference, particularly that of some United States' officials, in our domestic affairs,

    (c) calls upon the Government to be vigilant to all such groups and stop them from interfering in our domestic affairs, and

    (d) endorses the Government's detention, under the Internal Security Act, of the people involved in the attempt to subvert Singapore." - [Mr Goh Choon Kang].

    Question again proposed.

     The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Education (Mr Tang Guan Seng)( In Mandarin): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, ever since this Marxist plot was revealed until the Hendrickson affair, we have seen some very complicated and weird development. If people do not follow the sequence of these events, there would be a lot of confusion, because the people who are involved in it are not only people who are connected with the Malayan Communist Party, such as Tan Wah Piow who is now in England but also Marxists who disguised themselves in religious coats. There are also the diplomats of the superpower, the United States, who is reputed to be the pioneer anti-Communist champion. Not only are there domestic anti-government elements. but there are also some foreign groups including those of the human rights and newspapers and magazines. Certain things deemed impossible have happened one

Column: 230

after the other. Certain people of different interests and pursuits also unexpectedly appeared on the scene. So this matter has aroused much interest and talk among members of the public as to who is right and who is wrong.

    Since last week's heated debate on the motion raised by the Member for Braddell Heights and also on an amendment raised by the Member for Potong Pasir,as I can see, four types of public opinions on this matter have evolved.

    First, there are people who hold the view that the United States has not interfered with our domestic affairs, that the Government's action was aimed at suppressing the opposition. I call those who hold this view "the hardcore elements" and "the mischievous trouble-makers".

    Second, there are people who hold the view that although the United States has interfered in our internal affairs, we must give in and give way for the sake of the common interest. I call such people "trouble-shunners".

    The third view is that the United States has unreasonably interfered in our internal affairs and we have to take retaliatory measures to vent our anger. I call these people "radicals".

    The fourth view is that because of the special characteristics of our country, we should only make reasonable and measured response against the interference by the United States. I call these people who hold this view "pragmatic people".

    Mr Deputy Speaker, let me analyse the various groups of people before giving my own views.

    Who are these hardcore elements? They are members of the opposition parties. They have long held their own deep-rooted views regarding the policies of the Government and the People's Action Party and the characters of our leaders, with much dissatisfaction. No matter what evidence the Government might produce and whatever explanation the Government might give, they simply ignore them. They even distort the truth and view from the angle of an opposition political partisan. From viewing through coloured

Column: 231

glasses, they conclude that since the general election is coming, therefore the Government is now all out the to suppress the opposition. I feel that the Government has no need to waste time on or to spend effort to convince such people, because their ultimate purpose is to demolish the Government and to undermine the confidence the people have in the Government. In order to damage the People's Action Party and the Government, they would resort to any unscrupulous ways and means. They would even go to the extent of being made use of by foreign powers to achieve this purpose. As far as this small group of people is concerned, I think we can simply ignore them. However, we have to treat their distorted views seriously and counter them.

    In fact, I think we should pay more attention to another group of people who express views similar to those of hardcore elements. The trouble with them is that they like to make statements and when they are carried away by their emotions, they become unreasonable and unprincipled. The impression they give to the people is that they are also against everything. In actual fact they are unhappy with only some of the policies of the Government. They are not the opposition parties. It is exactly because of this that their talk and statements could create more harm and trouble. I earnestly urge them to seriously consider our national honour and interest, before they be so free in their talk. They should think more carefully and not be so irresponsible without considering the consequences of their action.

    As for those who are afraid of any trouble, "the trouble shunners", who are they? They are the people who are afraid that once the relationship between Singapore and the United States worsens, their livelihood may be affected. They are afraid that since Singapore is such a small country with close economic links with the United States which has substantial investments here employing many people, a strained relationship would place us in a very disadvantageous position. So to them, although the United States is wrong, we should try to play down the matter. We

Column: 232

should not raise the issue but should give in and try to make peace.

    I wish to point out that the leaders in our Government are the people who most understand the situation in Singapore. Not only are there close economic ties between Singapore and the United States, both have many views in common too on international affairs. We have mutual interests in international strategic considerations. We must consider whether we are prepared to pay a price for tackling the United States. But if we are to give in and compromise would it meet our interest, particularly our long term interest? In my view, the answer is no; it would not be in our interest. The reason is simple. If we are to quietly endure this US interference in our internal affairs, then we would have to be prepared to face interference by other countries. There are so many countries in the world bigger than Singapore which have come to invest and set up their factories here. They can all follow suit and threaten us saying, "Look here, this is what we want; you have to do it, otherwise we will withdraw our capital and move our factories from Singapore!" When that happens, where would our sovereignty and dignity be? When that happens, then although we are in name an independent country, we would be in fact a subordinate one at the mercy of the investor countries and the people of Singpapore would be subjects of these countries. Is this the type of Singapore that our people want? Absolutely not!

    As for the radicals, they feel that Singaporeans have been too courteous to the United States in this matter. The United States has interfered in our internal affairs. They are too much. They have gone beyond the limit. They consider themselves a super-power and the saviour for freedom and for democracy of other countries. In fact they are just trying to expand their power in disguise. Wherever they stretch their hands, the people and the Government there will be in trouble. We should take more drastic action like other countries to express the anger in our hearts. Otherwise the United States will take us to be a weakling. And after this they may repeat this sort of action against us. I do understand the feelings of the radicals, but I think their proposed action is

Column: 233

a bit overdone. Our Government is a mature government. Blind action or radical action will not be to our mutual benefit. I hope they will turn their anger into strength to support our Government.

    As for the "pragmatic people", basically they support the Government's measures. That means, for the sake of justice and upholding the sovereignty of this small island nation, we cannot tolerate the United States' interference in our internal affairs. But our reaction must be reasonable and measured. They stand behind the government. It is because they are convinced of the 20 years' achievements of this Government, trusting that whatever the Government does is to their benefit.

    Can we group all the people in Singapore into all these categories? No. There is yet one more group of people who have no opinion of their own. They follow what others say. I call them "waiverers". We have to be patient to explain to them and convince them. They cannot understand two points.

    They cannot understand why after repeated accusation by our government about US interference in our internal politics, the United States not only denied it categorically, saying that their diplomats had not done anything wrong, but also warned that if this were to continue, our traditional close relationship would be harmed.

    We all know that America is a super-power. Before we can resolve the Hendrickson matter, the President of the United States Mr Reagan is now busy having his summit meetings with the Russian leader Mr Gorbachev. My own view is that this is neither the first nor the last time of United States' inter -ference in the internal affairs of other countries. They will not admit their mistakes openly because they fear that by so doing they will lose their face internationally. But as Singaporeans, we must see this fact clearly. We should not have any doubt about the fact of inteference by the United States in our internal politics.

    To these "waiverers", they still have a doubt whether or not the United States has in fact bought over Francis Seow by supplying him with money. If that is

Column: 234

proven, then they will support the Government on the clear evidence that the United States has done wrong. As our Cabinet Ministers have pointed out, the matter is still under investigation. However, we must look at this matter as a whole, viewing its development objectively, and give our judgment. We cannot judge this matter solely on this one cue of suspected monetary supply. Because in the present world, black operators are highly professional. Such evidence definitely will not be detected so easily.

    In this debate, I believe, apart from the "hard-core elements", we have to persuade and convince all the other people in Singapore. We must win over their support on this important matter relating to our sovereignty and dignity. Thank you.

     Mr Abdullah Tarmugi (Siglap): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, I shall be brief.

    Sir, much heat and rhetoric has been generated in and outside this Chamber over foreign interference in our domestic affairs. That our people should feel aggrieved, even angry, over such meddling is understandable. But let, Sir, our objections be registered calmly, firmly and objectively and not flay about wildly, lest views turn into passion and words into regrettable action, for there may be groups which would gladly capitalize the situation to achieve their own ends, even here.

    I too, Sir, am all for putting the Hendrickson affair behind us and I hope the episode has served to register unequivocally our wish and resolve to be left alone in determining and managing our own affairs. I hope this has been just like two friends who have had a tiff and, emerging after it, understanding each other better, respecting each other even more.

    Sir, when he moved his amendment to this motion, the Member for Potong Pasir pointed out that the Hendrickson incident had not hurt Singapore. Have I heard you correctly?

     Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir): More or less.

     Mr Abdullah Tarmugi: More or less. I agree, Sir, but why? It is because we uncovered it in time before it could do any damage to us. It is because we have been

Column: 235

vigilant and that is why I support the motion by the Member for Braddell Heights.

    Sir, Singaporeans must realize just how open our society is, how exposed we are to influences and actions from outside. To be sure, this openness, this very exposure, have had their benefits and have played in no small way to the development of our nation. But we must also recognize the dark side of these attributes. In our cosmopolitan atmosphere wherein nationalities move and mingle about without sticking out like sore thumbs, imagine just how fertile this place is for intrigues to carry on, subversion to be hatched in hotel lounges. There are issues galore for the picking, to be raised, to be distorted and captitalized upon, running the whole gamut of race, religion, different concepts of freedom, different aspirations and so on. We can only be vigilant without stifling, firm without being inhibiting.

    Sir, our businessmen go abroad for business, our citizens go to foreign tourist spots for vacation and our students study in foreign universities. They are exposed to different ways of life, different shades of politics, different views. I am told, Sir, that even now Tan Wah Piow seeks out some of our students in the UK, invites them for tea, for lunches. I leave it to you, Sir, what could have been discussed at these meetings. These students return to Singapore. Could similar meetings between our students and the likes of Tan be held in other foreign countries too? I do not know. Perhaps. Will we therefore stop our students from going abroad for their studies? We cannot, Sir. This is how open we are, how exposed we are.

    Then there are pressure groups mentioned by the Foreign Affairs Minister and the Member for Kaki Bukit last week who paint Singapore in the darkest of colours, even those who have not yet stepped foot on our country. Is the picture fair? They have exaggeratedly cite the lack of individual freedom, individual rights. What about the freedom from hunger, freedom from unemployment, so long as one is willing to work, freedom from lack of shelter in Singapore? Are these not

Column: 236

important? Let us not be naive. Let us not idolize, as some do, all things western or everything that shouts "freedom". We must be more discernible. It is not that I respect freedom and rights less. It is just that I love Singapore more.

     Dr Koh Lam Son (Telok Blangah): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, I rise to speak in support of the motion standing in the name of the Member for Braddell Heights.

    Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, as the Member for Siglap has stated, much has already been said and debated about the US officials' interference in our domestic political affairs. I believe we have made our point clear to the United States and to the world that Singapore does not tolerate foreign interference. Although we are a small nation, we have spoken up with courage and have demonstrated our refusal to be intimidated. There is no need for me to belabour the point except to express my hope that both Singapore and the United States will become better from the experience.

    We regard the United States as our friend, an important trading partner and as the friendly super-power that defends all non-communist nations, including Singapore. And I do believe that even among the best of friends disagreement can happen from time to time. But as long as there is a spirit of friendship and as long as we are committed to the long-term mutual good, I am sure this incident will help us, both Singapore and the United States, to recognize our differences and to develop more meaningful ties in the future.

    But what continues to bother me is not the foreign interference but the wilful misinterpretation of the incident by people who are out to discredit the Government. For example, Sir, the Member for Potong Pasir has questioned and cast doubts on the statutory declaration made by Mr Patrick Seong. But as the Prime Minister has said to him last Friday, Mr Seong is now a free man and he is free to go and ask him personally the truth of the statutory declaration. He has also claimed that the PAP is using this debate to divert attention away from its problems. Nothing, Sir, can be further from the truth. The PAP is not facing any problem. In my

Column: 237

opinion, it is as strong as ever. In reality, it is the Opposition that is facing problems of credibility and reduced representation in Parliament, and the reason is obvious. It is the clean track record of the PAP Government that has made it very difficult for the Opposition to raise real issues. So it is understandable that they need to resort to trivial or imagined concern to make themselves heard.

    There are also those who would have the public believe that the Government is using this incident to systematically remove potential Opposition candidates from standing for election. Again, Sir, this is an unbelievable assertion. For we know, unlike the past, we now have a better educated and more discerning public. Opposition members or any aspiring politician must not only be outspoken and intelligent but they must have the moral integrity to command the confidence of the people. Expectations and standards are high today and those with severe flaws in character cannot hope to be successful. In fact, the Government is protecting the public interests by exposing these persons. We do not want the wrong person to come into this House. On the other hand, we encourage sincere and upright citizens to come in even if it means forming an Opposition to do so. After all, that was how the Member for Potong Pasir made it into this Parliament. So here there is no real issue.

    Also, Sir, there are those who hinted at the longer term political instability of Singapore to explain the US interference. Again, I fail to see the substance of this argument because in political terms the second generation leaders have positioned themselves well to ensure continued political stability. They are already in charge of Government and has been so for many years. They too have a good track record and the recent one is their performance in taking the nation out of the worst economic recession and into a period of unprecedented growth.

    Sir, in summary, I think it is important that, in the prolonged debate over this incident, we do not lose sight of the fundamental issues, and that only by exposing the subtle attempts to cloud basic issues and distort facts can we

Column: 238

ensure that the public will not be misled or misinformed.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Much obliged to you, Mr Deputy Speaker. The way the Member for Telok Blangah referred, I believe, to the arrest of the eight and still being detained persons as a trivial concern only goes to reflect his carelessness, his unfeeling, if not for the detainees at least for members of the detainees' families who are probably at this moment worried sick for their loved ones who are still in prison. I just cannot feel shocked that there is still a Member who has got no such feelings in this House.

    The issue that is uppermost in the minds of Singaporeans today is, of course, the arbitrary arrest of our young Singaporeans under the Internal Security Act. They are disturbed by the incarceration and the continued incarceration of the eight detainees, in particular, at the Government's appearance of carelessness and non-caring nature in not announcing when the remaining eight detainees will be released. Even in the case of a common criminal when he is convicted and sentenced to a jail sentence, he will be specifically told exactly how long he will have to remain in jail, whether it is six months, one year, or 10 years. Whatever the period of custodial sentence, he has a release date that will keep up his spirits and something to look forward to. In the case of our current lot of detainees, none of them know exactly how long they will stay behind bars. Is it going to be just the statutory 30 days or one year, two years, or 20 years like Chia Thye Poh? The fact that no release date is made known to the detainees or to their spouses or to members of their families, or even to their church members is itself a mental torture to them.

    Is this the act of a civilized government? Is it possible that our elected government is capable of such blatant acts against our own people, our own Singaporeans, our own flesh and blood? I want 76 hon. Members of this House to pause and contemplate what this Government has done to eight hapless Singaporeans. What are their crimes? Have they been found with knives, guns, grenades, mortars or other implements of war, whereby they

Column: 239

can wage a violent uprising against the Government and get law-abiding citizens killed? The answer, of course, is no. Have they been found to act prejudical to the security of Singapore, to the good order and essential services in this country? Again, the answer is no. So, what is the crime they have committed to warrant their arbitrary arrest, their imprisonment, and subjected to mental and psychological pressures? Psychologists will tell you that such pressures can in certain cases break a man or a woman irreparably.

    The Member for Braddell Heights and his seconder, the Member for Radin Mas, have bravely come to this House to support the Government's action to detain our fellow Singaporeans. They must. The first paragraph of their motion says so. But I would like to ask them: are they brave enough to meet the wives, husbands, members of their families and church members of the detainees, face to face, and answer their queries and perhaps their anger? We know that the Minister for Trade and Industry - I see he is not here - has decided not to make the trip to America with our Economic Development Board team to canvass for American investments in Singapore. I am sure he has good reasons. I shall be putting up a question in this House to ask for those reasons.

    I hope that, unlike our said Minister, the hon. Members will be willing to meet members of their families and their church members face to face. If they could give me their affirmative answers, I shall be willing to arrange for that meeting. Are they willing?

     Mr Goh Choon Kang (Braddell Heights): Does the Member want to give way?

     Mr Chiam See Tong: All right, but not too long. I have only 30 minutes.

     Mr Goh Choon Kang: Sir, I think the point here is whether the Member for Potong Pasir accepts the truth in the statutory declarations of these detainees.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: I give way only for him to answer the question. He refused to answer.

Column: 240



     Mr Goh Choon Kang: That is the point.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Say yes or no, please.

     Mr Goh Choon Kang: What is the point of meeting the family members of the detainees?

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Well, he should know. But before that, before I tell him the purpose, I have got to inform him that I have not contacted any of the detainees or any of the family members, and this is not a collusion to get hon. Members who have moved the motion and seconded it to meet the members of the families. This is voluntary and it is on my own initiative. Of course, the purpose of the meeting is for the members of the family, their wives, to tell you face-to-face the exact things their husbands, their wives have or have not done. Then you will know the truth.

     Mr S. Chandra Das (Chong Boon): Did their wives know the truth?

     Mr Chiam See Tong: And you can answer them face to face. Why not just accept this proposition and say yes? If you are not, obviously you are not a brave man. It is within the security of these four walls of this House you act like a brave man. I still get no answwer.

     Mr Goh Choon Kang rose.

     Mr Deputy Speaker: Mr Chiam, do you want to give way?

     Mr Chiam See Tong: All right. Yes or no?

     An hon. Member: No.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Are you afraid?

     Mr Goh Choon Kang: I think you are requested to interview Mr Patrick Seong since he is now a free man. And if you make the request, I think the Government would allow you to meet all the detainees to get the truth.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Please. I think I am not going to give way. You refused to answer. Now, I am not making all these allegations of their subversion. It is your Government, it is you. You are the one who is proposing in this House that they should be arrested and subjected to arbitrary imprisonment. You are the one

Column: 241

who says that they are Marxists, they are subverting our Government, overthrow our Government by violence, all kinds of accusations. You should be brave enough to confront them.

     Mr Goh Choon Kang: If the Member thinks that they are not, please produce evidence.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: All right, coming to the next point.

     Mr Deputy Speaker: He is not giving way.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Now, of course, the grave issue before this House is still the detention of the eight Singaporeans. And the issue is still whether they are Marxists, whether they are agents of foreign governments, whether they are a threat to the security of Singapore, and whether they have been assaulted and tortured as detainees. I think these are the issues. And, therefore, the rightful thing for the Government is to clear the air and have a public inquiry. There is no way out. If you really want the truth, get to the bottom of the matter, then there must be a public inquiry. Until a public inquiry is held, I am afraid whatever the Government tries to say day after day in this House will fall on deaf ears. Government has tried with the full force of the mass media, that is, the TV, radio, newspapers, under their control, to make its stories stick. But I say that the majority of the people of Singapore are sceptical. They do not believe what the Government tells them. The Americans who profess from the greatest democracy on earth do not believe that the detainees are Marxists. If they did, why should they attempt, according to the Government's allegations, cultivate them and encourage them to take part in the elections as independent candidates to oppose the Government? Are the Americans mad?

    The Member for Whampoa appeared to think so. He has suggested in this House on Friday that the Americans are out to sabotage our economy. And he is a Professor of Economics at NUS. I suppose he speaks two languages - one at NUS and one in this House. He must know that the Americans are our greatest foreign investor. They have direct investments of over US$2.3 billion and rising at the rate of

Column: 242

about US$200 million a year, making the United States the biggest foreign investor in Singapore. This bit of information was reported in this morning's Straits Times. It has been said by members of this Government before that the Americans do not invest massive amounts of money in Singapore because they love Singaporeans, but simply because it is good business for them to do so. They come here to make profits. They get a better return in Singapore for their investments than elsewhere.

    The reasons for the government wanting to invest in Singapore are purely economic. So it does not make sense. You put money in a place, you go and destroy that place. How crazy can Members of this House get when they accuse the American government of trying to sabotage Singapore? How do you expect Singaporeans to believe the PAP Government when some of its own members talk like that? It completely does not make sense. It boggles the mind.

    I think the more probable reason is the one that is circulating in the public. The Americans think that our Prime Minister is walking towards an uncovered manhole and they are trying to steer him away from this manhole. But, unfortunately, I think this Government thinks that the Americans are trying to push him in. So in this particular instance, I think the Government should give the benefit of the doubt to the Americans. Of course, it is against their Party's interests. But I want to make it very clear in this House that I do not condone or support foreign interference in our internal affairs, whether they be Americans, British, Chinese or any other foreign government, Chinese from the People's Republic or from Taiwan.

But I thought if anybody knows anything about the PAP Government's policy it has been to encourage the ownership of private property and indeed, Sir, according to the figures I have, 90% of all housing in

Column: 276

Singapore is privately-owned. [Mr Chiam See Tong interrupted.] If he wants to further this debate, he can file a Question. We can get more details from the Ministry of National Development.

    Then, Sir, he says there must be a public inquiry, a Commission of Inquiry. I think then I should mention here why did we in the first place decide to have a Commission of Inquiry and why did we decide not to have a Commission of Inquiry. When the First Deputy Prime Minister, the Minister for Trade and Industry and I and the Director of ISD met at the First Deputy Prime Minister's house on the evening of 18th April, two decisions were made. First, on the re-arrest of the eight detainees and the arrest of Patrick Seong. Second, that there should be a Commission of Inquiry. But why a Commission of Inquiry? It is because we were shocked and taken aback by the allegations in the joint statement. They were not just alleging ill-treatment but that they had been made to tell lies. They completely repudiated statements which they had made. In other words, they denied the case made against them by the Government last year which had been spelt out in great detail. In short, the joint statement said that the Government had fabricated the Marxist conspiracy, that the Government believed the ISD had concocted the whole thing and that the Government repeated a pack of lies to the people. These are very grave charges and we assume that they were serious in pursuing these charges of torture, ill-treatment which forced them to fabricate their statements. And if they persisted in their charges, there had to be a Commission of Inquiry to find out: was there a fabrication? What for? And by whom? We had to know. It was absurd because the Government does not arrest people on its whim and fancy. We do not fabricate things. This was why we have to have a Commission of Inquiry, we decided, and we were serious about it. The Attorney-General was asked immediately to frame the terms of reference. The Prime Minister, after his return to Singapore, consulted the Chief Justice on the afternoon of Monday, 25th April, as to which High Court Judge should head the Commission of Inquiry. The names for other Commissioners were also considered.

Column: 277



    But by Wednesday, 27th, or by 28th, the investigation reports on all of them had come in. They showed two things. First, that they were not acting as aggrieved parties seeking judicial or legal redress but were acting as political propagandists out to discredit the Government, to provoke agitation by outside groups, human rights groups, newspapers. In other words, the joint statement was a political propaganda ploy. This was clear from Patrick Seong's statutory declaration. Their intention was, first, to publish it when the Prime Minister was in Washington. What for? For maximum political embarrassment. Ng Bee Leng told us in the statutory declaration that the joint statement, first, was to discredit the Government in an election year and, second, to deter the Government from using the ISA. In other words, they were never really interested in a judicial or legal resolution of their grievances.

    Let us consider some of the salient points of their joint statement. First, it was very cunningly drafted, to have maximum emotional and political impact. Secondly, serious allegations were made but totally lacking in particulars or specifics. No specific facts - who was hit on the face, by whom? "Most of us were hit hard on the face." Who? "Some of us not less than 50 times." Again, who? No specifics. It was a collective accusation by nine persons about what happened to others where, in fact, each of them had been interrogated and questioned separately. Each can testify only about his or her own treatment and complain about such treatment. But none did. Instead, this collective accusation against an anonymous group of ISD officers. Thirdly, Sir, in making these very damning accusations, it is very strange that they themselves did not ask for an inquiry in the joint statement. But why not? In fact, they said, "We do not seek any official response." Sir, surely you would expect them to scream for some official response or follow-up action. Their position was, "Here, we are making these charges." That is all. Government need not do anything. Sir, we can liken it to a case of rape. You allege rape. You wait months after the event, months of silence, and then you make a report. Then you say, "Well, here I have made a report. I don't want any action to be taken."

Column: 278



    Consider also, Sir, that Tang Fong Har, one of the signatories who has fled, gave a BBC interview on 22nd April. She said many things, but not once did she speak about her own treatment. Here you have one of the signatories to the statement being given an opportunity on BBC to speak to millions of listeners, a golden opportunity to give a vivid account of how she was ill-treated, but she did not talk about the treatment. Instead, she talked about Chia Thye Poh and how she adored him.

    Sir, I have also pointed out that the signatories, the re-arrested detainees, made statutory declarations reaffirming the truth of what they had said and, except for Teo Soh Lung and two others, reiterating that they had not been assaulted. In other words, Sir, there was no fabrication. Once we concluded that they were out to make political propaganda and to launch a denigration campaign and not to pursue legal redress, we decided against the Commission of Inquiry for it would only mean political theatre for the one or two persons who still made allegations. As for that person, then the burden of proof is on that person to discharge in a proper forum, namely, in a court of law.

    Sir, I spent some time explaining this because of the points raised by the Member for Potong Pasir.

    Finally, Sir, Members have referred to the role of the foreign press. I would like to conclude by saying something on this. When the Government issued the press statement on 28th April and when we exposed the fact that the joint statement of certain ex-detainees was a political propaganda ploy to discredit the Government, we also predicted that there would be a massive campaign by the press. I quote:

    'Now that the ex-detainees have been re-arrested, the ensuing hysterical campaign against the Singapore government by the foreign press, especially the off-shore press, [that is, Asiaweek, Far Eastern Economic Review, Asian Wall Street Journal] and other regional publications is likely to be part of this scheme.'

    Sir, the events proved us right. As we predicted, the foreign press has indeed unleashed a truly hysterical campaign. Let me give you a few examples.

Column: 279

Bangkok Post, 11th May 1988, says:

    'Government critics welcomed. ... Critics welcome a campaign by an Australian human rights group urging tourists and business travellers to avoid Singapore until political activists held without trial are freed.'

But who are these critics whom they quote as supporting this boycott to hurt our economy? Only one - Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam.

    Before I go on to the Far Eastern Economic Review, Sir, I might mention that the Bangkok Post, unlike other papers in the region, has been avidly following recent developments in Singapore, particularly our case against Mr Hendrickson. But what is different is that the Bangkok Post reporting has shown very little interest in presenting a balanced picture, and they have gone out of their way to paint the ugliest picture of Singapore. In fact, it has been re-printing extremely negative articles about Singapore that have appeared in the Western media. Worse still, it has even published recently what purports to be a futuristic scenario entitled, "When nothing is left to bare". It is not emphasized in the headlines or anywhere else that this is a conjecture and one has to read very carefully at the date, "September 16, 1988". If one missed that, this is what one will read:

    'In a surprise development, First Deputy Prime Minister confirmed that a number of ISD officers had been detained under the ISA. Then the legal profession was declared officially restricted [meaning that lawyers can practise only if they work for the government].'

Somewhere else:

    '20,000 detainees are reportedly being held without trial.'

This is mischievous because if one did not read the fine print, one would get the impression that the article is talking about the present-day situation. Well, for what is worth, I think Members should note that the question is raised: whether the Bangkok Post has a brief to present Singapore in a certain way. Last year, the Bangkok Post was attacked by another major Thai daily newspaper for having been taken over by foreign capitalists.

Column: 280



    Far Eastern Economic Review, let me give a quote of 19th May 1988:

    'The Singapore Government has kept up its barrage of accusations of foreign manipulation of its local critics, again using as evidence sworn statements allegedly [allegedly] obtained from those critics while held in detention without trial.

    'Then: '... the ruling People's Action Party (PAP) appears intent on ramming through controversial legislation on the GRC.'

    Sir, but the best example of such hysterical campaign, and which I will single out, is the Asian Wall Street Journal which, as every one knows, recently lost its legal case challenging the Government's action against the Newspaper and Printing Presses Act. Within a period of two weeks, 10th May to 24th May 1988, the Asian Wall Street Journal carried three editorials on Francis Seow's arrest; three editorials which are worth noting for they give examples of campaigned journalism against Singapore.

    The first editorial, 10th May 1988, suggested that Mr Francis Seow's arrest had to do with the Asian Wall Street Journal's publication of Francis Seow's article, "Singapore's Closing Society", which we all know now was not written by him but was the handiwork of Mr Devan Nair. But just consider, Sir, how they link irrelevant matters with their editorial on Francis Seow's arrest. First, they referred to Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam as follows:

    'The government is now poring over Mr Seow's financial affairs, asking how he's been paying his phone bills these past 10 years. Similar inquiries led to the expulsion from Parliament last December of Mr Joshua B. Jeyaretnam.'

Note the word "expulsion", Sir. They did not mention anywhere in this editorial that Mr Jeyaretnam was not expelled by any decision of this House but he was disqualified by operation of law after a conviction of a criminal offence. They suppressed this information.

    Then they went on to talk about the GRC proposal, totally unrelated to Mr Francis Seow's arrest:

    'A team-candidate proposal now under study would also seem likely to keep the opposition from finding its way into government office. But Singapore's 2.6 million citizens aren't likely to benefit quite so much as the politicians of Mr Lee's ruling party.'

Column: 281

What has this got to do with the arrest?

    Then, Sir, second editorial, 17th May 1988. Without giving an explanation of the Government's case, they say:

    'The main complaint [of the government's case] seems to be that Mr Seow had chatted with an American diplomat. An American diplomat was expelled for talking to such people.'

This is a gross distortion of our case. Then, Asian Wall Street Journal irresponsibly spread the rumour that Mr Francis Seow had a heart attack, which was not true.

    Third editorial, Sir, of 24th May 1988. They say:

    'In recent years we've seen one of the two opposition members ... forced to resign after investigation into the finances of his Workers' Party.'

He was not forced to resign. So is this not an insidious repetition of a falsehood that Asian Wall Street Journal had sought to convey a misleading and untrue account of real political as well as legal events in Singapore?

    In all the articles, Francis Seow is described in glowing terms, "a prominent lawyer". Nowhere did they mention that he had been thrice disciplined. Nowhere did they say the Chief Justice described, in one case, his conduct as "deplorable conduct, dishonourable of him as a man and, dishonourable of his profession." In other words, Sir, they suppressed this information in the same way that they suppressed the fact that Mr Jeyaretnam was disqualified automatically because of a criminal conviction.

    We all know, Sir, that after Mr Francis Seow's statutory declaration was made public, it became known that Mr Devan Nair had written the article "Singapore's Closing Society". Did Asian Wall Street Journal inform the readers of this fact? The only way they did it, Sir, is that in the issue of 24th May, in an editorial they made a passing reference and said:

    'Mr Nair might have worked on the article published on May 10th.'

"Might have worked"? How can they brush this aside when Mr Francis Seow said, "Devan did the bulk of the work."?

    Sir, more significant is that there is a new twist, a new tactic, and stepping up of

Column: 282

their campaign against Singapore. Previously they tried to give a semblance of reporting on the facts while commenting on the editorial. Now, they have decided to forgo reporting and openly campaign against us.

    Members will know that on Monday, 23rd May, First Deputy Prime Minister, Minister for Trade and Industry and I gave a press conference where Asian Wall Street Journal's correspondent was present. You saw him on TV, John Berthelsen. He asked loaded questions, why Francis Seow is detained for attempting to practise democracy in Singapore. The following day, Asian Wall Street Journal ran an editorial which was a frontal attack on the Government, but without any reporting, without any mention of the press conference. No mention of the press conference at all. In fact, Asian Wall Street Journal did not report on the first press conference given by the three Ministers.

    Sir, this is clearly campaign journalism. Asian Wall Street Journal has made it abundantly clear that it has abandoned any pretense of neutrality of reporting on events and on the Francis Seow's question as well as on more general policies. They have unambiguously taken sides against the Government. They have now decided to black out our press conferences and our viewpoint, while carrying hostile editorials with the distortions that I have referred to.

    Sir, in the weeks and months ahead we can expect more of this from Asian Wall Street Journal as well as others. They have shown that they are not an offshore press reporting on Singapore for outsiders. They are openly campaigning against Singapore and we have to deal with them on that basis. Thank you, Sir.

     The Minister for the Environment (Dr Ahmad Mattar): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, I rise in support of the motion standing in the name of the Member for Braddell Heights.

    Sir, after Government's exposure of Hendrickson's interference in our domestic politics, I held several discussions with a number of people, both young and old. While the older ones amongst them, particularly those who had witnessed similar interferences in the past, are solidly

Column: 283

behind Government's action, there are those amongst the younger ones who feel uneasy about the exposure. They think it is foolhardy for a small country like Singapore to offend a superpower like the United States. Then there are those who want an end to what they call "the rhetoric on the Hendrickson's affair." Yet, there is another category of Singaporeans, naive perhaps, who call for the periodic re-evaluation of the Internal Security Act (ISA) to see "what latitude may be allowed".

    Sir, on the ISA, I do not intend to repeat what the Prime Minister had succinctly put across in this House last Friday. All I would like to emphasize is that we need the ISA and in its present form. The Government will stand by its record. We will defend the ISA.

    Sir, indeed the United States is a superpower. But should we keep quiet when her officials meddle in our domestic politics? True, Sir, Singapore is a small country. But must it suffer foreign interference and subversion in silence? And I address foreign interference and subversion as two separate issues. Foreign interference impinges upon our sovereignty but foreign subversion cuts at our survival. And it is because we are a small country, not only must our sovereignty be protected but there is also no room in our political arena to accommodate foreign subversive activities.

    Sir, all self-respecting Singaporeans should feel outraged by foreign interference and subversion rather than be afraid of offending them. They should come forward and, in one voice, censure the surreptitious operation of US State Department officials who actively encouraged and instigated some lawyers and a number of professionals who are unhappy with the Government to contest against the ruling party in the coming General Elections.

    Sir, if you still remember, about a fortnight ago my colleague, the Minister for Trade and Industry, disclosed that a number of US officials and Congressmen had quietly asked Singapore not to make

Column: 284

public its findings on the investigations into detained lawyer Francis Seow. Should Government allow itself to be deterred from disclosing the findings of its investigations into Seow and hurriedly close the case instead? I say, Sir, Singaporeans have every right to know Francis Seow's role in this American interference in our domestic affairs. The Government cannot bow to American pressure. It owes it to the people to make public the findings of its investigations, however embarrassing they may be to the Americans. That was how American meddlings in our domestic politics were dealt with in the past. This is how we deal with it now. We expose them. We do not hide them.

    Sir, a strong, efficient and clean government has existed in Singapore for more than two decades now. This is the choice of Singaporeans, and no foreign government, mass media or human rights group has the right to interfere with and influence the choice of Singaporeans.

    In a democracy, it is the legitimate political right of citizens to take part in politics, to oppose the ruling party or even replace it through elections. But if they participate at the instigation of and with financial assistance from foreign elements, they will lose their political integrity and end up as tools for foreign subversion. Singaporeans by all means should take a keen interest and participate actively in politics. But they must at all costs preserve their political integrity. They must not allow themselves to become easy prey to manipulation by foreign elements and become their proxies.

    Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, the US State Department has hitherto denied that its officials had interfered in our internal politics. The Americans are not likely to remove the fig leaf they have put up. Diplomatically, Sir, this is a face-saving device but it would not do any good to the fostering of ties between the US and her friends. It is most unwise to adopt this fig-leaf policy in the face of conclusive evidence and especially when such an unpleasant incident happens to a friendly nation. Sir, exonerating errant officials unreservedly can only give the impression of insidiousness and irrationality, unbecoming of a great nation.

Column: 285



    Sir, if the US Embassy here and the State Department in Washington had reprimanded the errant officials based on facts and evidence and apologized, as they had done in 1961 over improper activities in Singapore by certain US officials, they would have done better in preserving their esteem and dignity and in reinstating their conviction in the sovereignty of nations as a basic human right. But their continued refusal to acknowledge this interference, Sir, has not helped matters. And as long as the US administration continues to exonerate errant officials and tries to turn black into white, it will only anger self-respecting Singaporeans further.

    Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, the Singapore Government has reacted soberly, rationally and with restraint to this incident. Let us hope that the US State Department can react likewise.

     Encik Zulkifli bin Mohammed (Eunos): (In Malay): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, I support the motion standing in the names of the Members for Braddell Heights and Radin Mas.

Although the large majority of Singaporeans do not welcome this, there are still some quarters who have doubts about this incident. Yes, it is true that the episode is hard to believe. But those who have been following the history and development of international politics will not be surprised that this had happened. It showed us to that a country one considers a friend can also have officials who would act like our foes. This is one of the realities of international relations which Singaporeans must accept.

    Another reality is that this controversy is no trivial matter but a national issue affecting the integrity and honour of Singaporeans and the sovereignty and independence of our nation. Thus, the reaction that we have shown is not without basis but something that is appropriate and measured mindful that this issue is not a mere fabrication. This careful response is the best course of action as we do not wish to violate the principles governing relationships between two independent, sovereign nations. We must not forget that the objective of relations between friendly

Column: 286

nations is to build enduring ties on the basis of mutual trust and confidence. In this respect, I was relieved to hear the explanations given by the Deputy Prime Minister and other Ministers that the exposure of this interference is not meant to seek a quarrel with the superpowers or with any parties but is intended to show how vulnerable Singapore is to foreign interference.      The First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Defence (Mr Goh Chok Tong): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, many Ministers and MPs have spoken, some with anger and outrage, others with dismay and sorrow. As expected, there was a range of opinions on how strongly we should protest to the US government. Our MPs represent a cross-section of Singaporeans, in age, social background and experience. We have allowed them to speak freely so that we can appreciate better the public sentiments on this issue. They varied in pitch, but no one doubted that Hendrickson, Snyder and Lambertson were interfering in our domestic affairs. I share the same sense of outrage and indignation as do the most emotional of Ministers and MPs. But as a Deputy Prime Minister, I cannot allow emotion to blind me. I must register my indignation, my feelings, in a temperate manner.

    I do not want to permanently damage relations with a friend, even though what Hendrickson and company have done has already hurt ties between the US and Singapore. We value these ties. We do not want to diminish their strength. We know where our national and long-term interests lie. We know who have been and should continue to be our friends. But we have to register our point. And our point is: no outsider, not even a good friend, should meddle in our internal affairs. If we fail to

Column: 287

get this point acknowledged, then all foreign powers will conclude that Singaporeans are fair game. And,in time, the Singapore Parliament will be a mini-United Nations. Each group of MPs will represent a different country, while wearing Singapore colours. We will have lost our independence while remaining sovereign. You have to see our strong reaction in this perspective, not just the perspective of fearing that our strong protest will damage ties with the US.

American Interference an Affront

    The venture by Hendrickson to get Francis Seow to organize a group of disaffected lawyers to contest the coming General Elections is an affront to Parliament. Members will recall that this House oassed the Legal Profession (Amendment) Bill in October 1986. This amendment sought to prevent crooked lawyers from serving on the Council of the Law Society. Crooked lawyers are those who have been convicted of fraud or dishonesty, or who have been suspended from practice for six months or more.

    When this Bill became law, Francis Seow had to step down as President of the Law Society. He had been disciplined three times before by the Law Society. The first time was in 1973, when he acted as counsel in the Gemini Chit Fund case. A Court of three Judges sentenced him to one year's suspension for "grossly improper conduct". The Chief Justice said this of him, and I quote him:

    'he [that is, Francis Seow] was guilty of grossly improper conduct in discharge of duties. It was wholly deplorable conduct dishonourable of him as a man and dishonourable of his profession.'

The second time was in 1975: A Disciplinary Committee reprimanded him on a complaint that he attested, ie affixed a seal before him when in fact he did not witness it. The third time was in 1982, barely six years ago, when he was disciplined for getting his practising certificate by false declaration. The Chief Justice said:

    'the respondent's explanation relating to a matter governing his continued right to practise his profession defies credulity and no reasonable tribunal could have any doubt that he was aware of the statutory disqualifying provision when he made the statutory declaration.'

Column: 288



    Hendrickson must have known the details. He watched the proceedings of the Select Committee which discussed the Legal Profession (Amendment) Bill. For him to encourage Francis Seow to enter this House, after Parliament had passed legislation disqualifying him from the Council of the Law Society, is to insult Parliament. It is a grave affront to Members. The law regarded Francis Seow as unfit to be a Council member of the Law Society. Hendrickson considered him deserving of a seat in this Chamber which makes laws. Would the State Department endorse such a man to run as a candidate for the US Congress?

Interference sets in motion chain of events

    Whether Hendrickson intended it or not, his operation, had it succeeded, would have done Singapore grave harm. It would have set in motion a chain of events which could undermine the integrity of Parliament, alter the nature of our politics, and eventually, break up the cohesion of our society. Let me explain.

Integrity of Parliament

    After watching Francis Seow on television, Hendrickson decided that this was a leader who could take on the Prime Minister, defy him and, perhaps, demolish him. He never understood why Patrick Seong, a Singaporean, was reluctant to associate himself with Francis Seow. Suppose Francis Seow gets into Parliament. Other scallywags and charlatans follow him or accompany him into Parliament. The integrity of Parliament becomes suspect. Politicians, you, I, the Member for Potong Pasir, get discredited. Moral respect for those who govern is lost. Where is the moral authority to govern?

    Interfering in our domestic politics is wrong in itself. But Hendrickson chose a man whose personal character and professional conduct were the opposite of what Singaporeans expect their leaders to be. He was undermining a basic traditional strength of our society - that only honourable men and women should be in Parliament. It is this lack of understanding of our society and our philosophy of government which upsets us. We could have lost a most valuable asset which we have built up over the last 30 years.

Column: 289



Clash of Cultures affects our Politics and Cohesion

    I am prepared to believe that Hendrickson probably meant Singapore no harm, and was acting out of ignorance. Indeed, he may even have thought that instigating and contriving an effective Opposition led by Francis Seow was good for Singapore. I am prepared to believe that - that he was doing this out of the goodness of his heart or out of the belief that Singapore would have been more open because of an effective Opposition to check the Government. But he did not understand our society. He was ignorant of our philosophy of government. He had no idea that he was doing immense harm to Singapore had his scheme succeeded.

    The good intentions of ignorant American officials have led to disasters before. Let me give you an example. Iran.

Iran

    In Iran before the revolution, the United States supported the Shah as a strategic ally in the Middle East. When the Shah faced domestic problems, the US pressed him to yield ground to his opponents, instead of leaving him to deal with the situation firmly.

    Americans attacked the Shah for persecuting the Shah's opponents, and ridiculed him for not even leaving the most harmless and ineffective of them alone, a peaceful, saintly old man who lived in exile in France called Ayatollah Khomeini.

    Since the Shah depended on American support, especially for equipping his armed forces, he had no choice but to heed American preferences. He tried to introduce in Iran American democratic ideals of power sharing and elected representative government. Unfortunately, Iran was a traditional Muslim society already caught in the throes of modernization. Irrelevant American ideas and cultural values worsened the upheavals, and eventually contributed to the overthrow of the Shah.

    The end-result for the Iranians is the Khomeini government. Whatever the shortcomings of the Shah, nobody believes this is an improvement.

Column: 290



    As for the Shah himself, after being a loyal friend of the Americans for so many years, and after losing office, in part because he heeded American advice, when he was mortally ill with cancer, he found that he was not even welcomed to stay in the United States for medical treatment. He spent his last days, poor man, in Egypt, where President Sadat was the only one in the world willing to give sanctuary to him.

    Maybe that was why Francis Seow was so keen to pin the Americans down on their assurance of asylum, right from the start. Otherwise if things go wrong, he may end up with the fate of the Shah.

Possible end-result for Singapore

    When Hendrickson chose Francis Seow to lead an effective Opposition in Singapore, he was applying American political culture to a Singapore, Asian society. Does he know what the end-result will be? Can he know? Can he predict, as in the case of Iran? Did the Americans predict the end-result for Iran?

    Had we mishandled this operation to discredit us, had we reacted tamely to the joint press statement of the nine former detainees, the people will be confused, even angry, believing in the allegations of torture and believing that the detainees were wrongly detained. And with Hendrickson still operating in Singapore, helping Francis Seow to recruit people like Patrick Seong, Seow might well have been able to persuade 40 to 50 professionals, lawyers, accountants and others to join him, especially if they sensed that the Government was fumbling. And if the elections go wrong, and they win 20 to 30 seats or even more, there will be a total transformation of our society and the nature of our politics.

    Politics will become contentious with each group vying for power and, in trying to do so, appealing to gut feelings of race, language, religion, culture. Could Hendrickson, no matter how well-meaning he was, foresee the consequences of this politics of contention for a multi-racial society like Singapore?

    Singapore society is made up of disparate and different component parts - different races, different religions,

Column: 291

different languages, different cultures, criss-crossed by more differences. Patiently, slowly, and laboriously, the PAP Government has brought these disparate components together.

    Now there is a coalition of interests between different racial, linguistic and religious groups. If this coalition can hold and bind itself together, firmly, then in another one or two generations a more integrated society may emerge, one which can begin to divide along socio-economic lines, not along race, language, culture and religion. But if before this unity is established, the ground is confused and fractured, the different and disparate parts will come loose. If that happens, and I speak here frankly, it is doubtful whether we the second generation leaders, or any other group, will have the same experience, or get the same degree of trust from the people, to re-assemble and re-glue the various parts and pieces to overcome their gut loyalties to race, language, culture and religion.

    Once the old fault lines are re-opened, those contending and seeking to win political support, will revert to the natural and most effective way of gaining support, and that is, to appeal to the primeval emotions of people, that of race, language, culture and religion. Then we shall end up like many other Third World countries. Thirty years of bonding and building a nation out of disparate groups will come to nought.

Singapore - not like South Korea, Taiwan or the Philippines

    US officials have no right to interfere in our domestic affairs. They do not even have the moral authority to sermonize to us on human rights and democracy. When the US State Department officials claim that all the activities of Hendrickson in Singapore were normal activities of an American diplomat, I can believe them. I can quite believe that they participate actively in trying to re-shape the political future of South Korea, Taiwan and the Philippines, amongst other countries. But Singapore is not Taiwan, South Korea, or the Philippines. We have no historical links

Column: 292

with the United States. South Korea, Taiwan and the Philippines have.

South Korea

    Americans bore the brunt of the Korean war in 1950. They fought to contain communism and stop the North Koreans from overrunning all of Korea. They suffered 140,000 casualties. 30,000 Americans died in Korea. Today, American troops are still playing a vital role in South Korea's security. South Korea also received billions of dollars, US dollars, in foreign aid, both military and economic. Given the nature of this relationship between South Korea and US, the US can exercise moral influence on South Korea's political development.

Taiwan

    As for Taiwan, US support was crucial to its survival. The older MPs amongst us might remember that during the Quemoy crises in 1954 and 1958, when Taiwan was in real danger of invasion, destroyers from the US Seventh Fleet patrolled the Taiwan Straits. Aircraft from the US Air Force deterred any rash moves by the PRC, and the US hinted that they were considering the use of nuclear weapons. Taiwan had a mutual security pact with the US until 1979 when the US established diplomatic relations with the PRC. The US has also contributed significantly to Taiwan's economic rehabilitation, growth and present prosperity. The US has frequently intervened into what are strictly Taiwan's domestic affairs, especially opposition politics. They get away with it because US support is crucial for Taiwan.

Philippines

    As for the Philippines, US involvement dates back to 1898 when they took over the islands from Spain. At the start of World War II, the Japanese captured Philippines. The US fought hard to liberate the islands from the Japanese in 1944. 200,000 troops were involved. 14,000 Americans were killed. If I were a Filipino, I would feel obligated to the Americans, for the sacrifice of American lives for Filipino freedom. Indeed, that was how President Magsaysay felt when he campaigned for his Presidency in 1953. He said:

    'The Republic of the Philippines is America's baby. We're in the same family.'

Singapore

    But Singapore is not America's baby. We are nobody's baby. We are not an American responsibility. American troops never fought on our soil to defend our freedom. They have no military or defence obligations to Singapore. We never had an umbilical cord to the US, unlike Taiwan, South Korea and the Philippines. They have or had defence treaties which made them US allies. South Korea and the Philippines still play host to US armed forces.

    Moreover, Taiwan and South Korea are divided nations with no membership of the United Nations, and they have problems over their international status. This makes their links with the US matters of life and death. They have to heed US advice, even on some domestic matters. We are not in such a position. We are not an ally with a formal treaty with the US. We are simply friends, good friends.

    Our links were with Britain. We have a Five Power Defence Arrangement with Britain, Australia, New Zealand and Malaysia. Even then, no British diplomat had dared to interfere in our domestic affairs. No British diplomat had dared to do what Hendrickson, Snyder and Lambertson did. We are under no obligation whatsoever to put up with American sermonizing and interference. We do not have to accept their notions of human rights or their ideals of government or their efforts to make us more like a western society.

Russell Kirk on Human Rights

    Dr Russell Kirk, whom the Member for Jalan Kayu has quoted before, is a Distinguished Fellow of the Heritage Foundation. This is an American conservative think-tank in Washington. He wrote about the American "Illusion of Human Rights" in his book "The Wise Men Know What Wicked Things Are Written on the Sky", and I quote him:

    'It is not the mission of the United States to establish universally some imitation of the American political and economic order. Every people must find their own way to order and justice and freedom.'

I wish the US State Department officials will take note - "Every people must find their own way to order and justice and freedom."

ACTION UNDER INTERNAL SECURITY ACT


    Debate resumed.

     Mr Goh Chok Tong: Dr Kirk added, and I quote him:

    'It is much to be desired that the recovery of order and justice and freedom be advanced throughout the world; we should be thankful, in this rough time, for small mercies. But international politics, like domestic politics, is the art of the possible. To demand that other countries swiftly attain the liberal ideal is to expect what they cannot possibly accomplish; in some cases, it is to expect them to work their own destruction.'

That means, in some cases, when you force your ideal on them, you get them to work for their own destruction.

    'Also this is a demand often disingenuous, sometimes hypocritical. The United States supports by gigantic loans the murderous despot who rules Zaire, because now and again he may serve our turn in Africa; but our diplomats do not trouble themselves to inquire keenly into his enforcement of "human rights". Our State Department sedulously refrains from any words that might annoy the masters of Yugoslavia, where any hope of regaining some degree of civil liberty has been blasted as thoroughly as in Poland; for Yugoslavia is a bulwark of sorts against the Soviet Union. We reserve our sermons concerning human rights for such allies and client states as could not or would not break with the United States under any circumstances.'

    I do not necessarily agree with Dr Russell Kirk's assessments of the countries which he has named, but I have no doubt that Americans apply double standards when it comes to human rights. Human rights groups like Asiawatch kick up no fuss over Middle Eastern countries where adulterers are stoned to death and where the right hands of thieves are chopped off in accordance with Islamic Law because these countries produce oil which America needs. Double standards!

    US concern over human rights in the Soviet Union, which President Reagan once referred to as the "Evil Empire", has not prevented him from holding four summits with General Secretary Gorbachev, or Nancy Reagan from holding hands with

Column: 295

Raisa Gorbachev. The Soviet government knows that they can ignore US sermons about human rights and religious freedom, and despite this the US will have no alternative but to continue to do business with the Soviet Union. The US knows this too.

    In interfering in Singapore's affairs, Hendrickson must have believed that we were more pliable, and that, like the Mafia Godfather, we have to do his bidding. But he forgot that Singapore is neither a client state of the United States nor an ally who cannot break away. We are a friend, a close friend of United States, I would like to believe. But if this closeness means that the US officials feel that they have a right to select and support Singaporeans they fancy as the leaders of the Opposition to work against us, then we shall keep our distance from them. We can move into a more neutral and a non-aligned posture.

Systems of Government

    Perhaps there is a reason for what I see as an inherent American suspicion of government and why they believe in multi-party politics. The American Constitution, and here I am quoting one Dr Freeman Dyson:

    'The American Constitution is designed to be operated by crooks, just as the British constitution is designed to be operated by gentlemen.'

I can tell you that the Foreign Minister was most unhappy that I should be quoting this. He advised me, I think at least two times, not to say this, that it would annoy the Americans. But this is not necessarily my view. I am just quoting from a very distinguished American. This quote comes from his new book "Infinite In all Directions", which was reviewed by the International Herald Tribune (30th April 1988). And according to the reviewer, Dr Dyson is a "theoretical physicist, at Princeton's august Institute for Advanced Study, veteran defence consultant and, neuron for neuron, one of the most formidably provocative minds in American life".

    To say that the American Constitution "is designed to be operated by crooks" is perhaps a colourful exaggeration. But it does underline the American view of poli-

Column: 296

tics and government, and also underline their view of politicians. Reading American magazines and newspapers, I get the impression that Americans generally believe that no one should be entrusted with wide powers because sooner or later he is bound to abuse them. So they place great faith in checks and balances - minimum of powers to the elected President, and the maximum of controls of the Executive by Congress and the Supreme Court, and the media. So the media take it upon themselves to scrutinize and monitor the President and his staff in order to detect and expose wrongdoings.

    But we are not America. The Singapore system, like the British, entrusts the Executive, the Prime Minister and the Cabinet, with a range of wide discretionary powers, for example, the right to detain drug traffickers and gang rapists under the Criminal Law (Temporary Provisions) Act. The British system of Cabinet government with a majority in Parliament (because to be in Parliament you must have a majority) means strong government.

    On this constitutional framework, Singaporeans have superimposed the ideal political leader as a Confucian gentleman, a Jun zi (    ), someone who is upright, morally beyond reproach, someone people can trust. We believe that leaders must be men of ability and integrity, committed to the public good. If I may quote in Mandarin from Confucius "Zheng zhe zheng ye, zi shuai yi zheng, shu gan bu zheng" (    ) "To govern is to set things right. If you begin by setting yourself right, who will dare to deviate from the right?"

    Singaporeans expect their Prime Minister, and indeed any Minister, any MP, to be a superior man, a man of ability and integrity who can set things right and ensure good government. He must be a "Jun zi", a Confucian gentleman.

    American politics is totally different from ours. The brightest and the best do not get, as a rule, elected into government. As a rule, they do not run for elected office. They make their mark in the private corporations, and the best make it to the top. The Fortune magazine regularly publishes the top 500 companies in the United States, and the best and the brightest in

Column: 297

America make it to these top 500 corporations in the US.

    Those Americans who run for elections need a strong stomach for physically gruelling election campaigns more than anything else. So what you need in the US is a strong stomach because if you do not have a strong stomach, you cannot survive the months, and even years, of campaigning. And the winners are those who are telegenic, who are skilled communicators, never mind if they are helped by ghost writers or wordsmiths who can craft beautiful phrases to fit the headlines.

    So when Hendrickson picked Francis Seow as a potential leader of the Opposition, he was pressing a button that could have upset and dismantled the carefully built-up moral standards of our Parliament, the high standards of leadership which have held and still hold Singapore together. It is this extrapolation of consequences which upsets us, not just the impropriety of interfering in our domestic politics. Once you press the button you set in motion a chain of events. And can you foresee the consequences?

    I feel strongly on this point about Jun zi being in Parliament because I believe that that is the way for us to govern Singapore, for us to hold the place together. I have now been in politics for 12 years. I have worked with the Prime Minister and his Old Guard colleagues, Dr Goh Keng Swee, Dr Toh Chin Chye, S. Rajaratnam, E.W. Barker, Ong Pang Boon and Lim Kim San, to identify and recruit candidates for the PAP, and to help them get elected into Parliament. I ran the by-elections in 1979. I was Chairman of the General Elections Committee for the PAP in 1980 and also in 1984. From 1980, I searched, sieved, and sat in at all the interviews of all new candidates for Parliament. Amongst the PAP MPs here, I think I am not wrong in saying that I have the deepest inside knowledge of how PAP Members of Parliament were spotted by the Prime Minister, by the Old Guard leaders, how they were scrutinized and assessed for their social commitments, their character and, finally, how they were selected to stand for elections for the PAP. I nominated some Members of Parliament myself - the Members of Parliament for Ayer Rajah, Kebun Baru,

Column: 298

Eunos, the Minister for Trade and Industry, the Minister for Community Development. I was involved in their nominations, in their being assessed by the Committee of the PAP and in their final selection. And I would like to think I played a part in getting them elected into Parliament.

    We did not just look for ability in our MPs, an important point worth making, because people believe that we look only for ability in our MPs. No, there are other attributes that we look for. Important attributes like integrity, reliability, moral standards, motivation for wanting to be an MP, and whether he has done things for others without expectation of personal gain. We studied the life history of our candidates and checked with their friends. That is how thorough we are. The ability, character and moral standing of the Ministers and the MPs are at least equal to, if not better than, the top executives in the corporations, in the private sector, or in the media. And where they have not measured up, they are dropped, as MPs know. Where they have broken the rules, they are punished. This is how we maintain standards. This is why the people of Singapore do not despise their political leaders. This is why they do not despise their MPs.

    We have to maintain standards. If not, a Parliament of able and moral men, who look after the interests of the people, will degenerate into a Parliament of immoral and opportunistic men whose concerns are themselves, or worse, their outside masters. Once Parliament is not filled with upright men, or "Jun zi" (    ), or what Confucius called "Xiao ren" (    ), "mean men", the whole system of government, and then the whole society, must disintegrate.

    I remember when I visited London in September 1986, this question was asked of me by an official of the Conservative Party. I visited their Central Office. He asked me, "What is the social standing of politicians in your country?" I told him, "Very high" and said, "What's yours?" His reply was, "Politicians are right at the bottom." Then he corrected himself and said, "No. Journalists are below them." He was referring to Western journalists.
