Foreign press, human rights groups

    The Western press and the so-called human rights groups have not understood this reason for our outrage, this reason for our wanting to maintain very high standards for Parliament. They were accessories of Hendrickson in building up Francis Seow as a "great human rights champion of oppressed Singaporeans". Out of nowhere, Francis Seow became a "leading dissident", a "sharp critic", a "prominent lawyer", a "human rights champion". He was invariably referred to by the offshore press as a former Solicitor-General, and a former President of the Law Society, both highly honourable professions. They never told their readers why Francis Seow resigned from the Civil Service, why he was disciplined three times by the Law Society, what the Chief Justice said of him and why he was disqualified as President of the Law Society, and why Patrick Seong refused to share the same political bed with him. They dressed him up in fine clothing. They were dressing up a wolf in sheep's clothing.

    The Bangkok Post, Hong Kong papers, the Far Eastern Economic Review, the Asian Wall Street Journal, Asiaweek, they all painted him up as a leading opposition figure in Singapore. They were campaigning for him, building him up as a great figure to save Singapore from tyranny. These papers were and still are participating actively in our domestic politics. They are active participants, not neutral observers. Like Hendrickson, they are interfering in our domestic politics and trying to shape its course.

    Francis Seow has such a dubious reputation that even Patrick Seong was afraid to associate with him. Yet, the offshore press and the human rights groups were puffing him up into a Singapore leader, a glorious knight in shining armour.

    We can easily expose this hypocrisy by asking them this simple question. If Francis Seow were running as a US presidential candidate, would you puff him up or would you puncture him? Remember what they did to Gary Hart and Senator Joe Biden? Senator Biden was laughed out of the US presidential race for plagiarism

Column: 300

as a university law student. Yet the Asian Wall Street Journal did not seem embarrassed even after learning that Francis Seow's article on "Singapore's Closing Society" was not written by him. If the offshore press continue to actively engage in our domestic politics and try to sway the ground before the next general elections against the Government, we shall counter them. We see little reason to accord them the privilege of stationing correspondents here to interfere in Singapore's domestic politics.

Confidence in US shaken

    I cannot pretend that our confidence in the US State Department has not been shaken by the adventures of Hendrickson, Snyder and Lambertson. It will be a lie if I say that our relations are as good as ever, that our confidence in the US State Department has not been shaken. We had a good steady relationship with the US. Why they want to upset this relationship is something which I cannot understand. We find it most worrying that the US government should insist that they have done nothing wrong and that the activities of Hendrickson were within the normal duties of a diplomat. Perhaps it is standard practice to deny such diplomatic transgressions. But if cultivating and nurturing disaffected elements to oppose an elected government is legitimate activity for American diplomats, then we had better take care, and so will other governments. For we must assume that Hendrikson's successors will mount another quiet operation against us, 5, 10, 15 years from now.

    Since this unhappy episode, I have asked how we can safeguard ourselves. The answer comes down to a vigilant ISD, and a more manageable number of diplomatic staff in the foreign embassies. I have looked at the staff strength of the various embassies in Singapore - USA, UK, Japan, Australia, Indonesia, Thailand, Malaysia, Canada, France, USSR and FRG. The US embassy has 22 diplomatic staff and 44 home-based, non-diplomatic, staff, a total of 66. The Soviet embassy, in sharp contrast, is allowed only 8 diplomatic staff and 18 home-based, non-diplomatic, staff, a total of 26, or one-third of the Americans. If American diplomats behave as if they have a missionary right to roam all over

Column: 301

Singapore, including off-limit areas, whether such behaviour is official US State Department policy or not, then we have no choice but to cut down their diplomatic staff strength. Otherwise, it will be impossible for us to patrol and keep interfering diplomats off the forbidden areas. This will be unpleasant but it may be the only way to preserve good relations with the US in the long run.

Conclusion

    We have long regarded the United States as a good friend, a close friend, whose strategic interests we share. If the US understands our sensitivity and respects our wish to be ourselves, we can remain close friends. The Singapore Government is answerable to Singaporeans. We have to account for our actions every four or five years in free and secret elections. Foreigners are not accountable for their actions. When they interfere in Singapore and things go wrong, they are not accountable. We are. They do not stand for elections in Singapore. We do. Can Hendrickson, Snyder and Lambertson rescue us if Singapore go down the drain?

    Many people have felt that the Government has over-reacted, the Member for Ayer Rajah amongst them. But someone also told me that Singapore's reaction is too mild. Had Hendrickson been exposed in a neighbouring country, American flags would have been burnt and the US embassy stoned. So our reaction is very subdued. In my view, this controlled rage and quiet indignation, is a good sign for US-Singapore relationship.

    In February this year, when the US withdrew the GSP from Singapore, you remember the NTUC held a rally. Workers demonstrated. Some used quite strident, anti-American, language. The Prime Minister was worried at the intemperate language used. He expressed his concern in a letter to Cabinet, and I quote him:

    'Once we have worked the ground, it is very difficult to sway them back to view Americans as friends.'

In other words, in our protest, remember that we should not sway the ground in

Column: 302

such a way that we begin to regard Americans as our enemy. I shared the Prime Minister's concern. I had, in fact, earlier advised the NTUC to confine its rally to the Singapore Conference Hall. The NTUC wanted to organize a big rally at the Padang and then march or have a foot procession, all the way to the US embassy. But because I shared the Prime Minister's concern (we did not discuss) I advised the NTUC to hold its rally indoors. Otherwise, the Prime Minister would have sent his Cabinet colleagues a stiffer note.

    This time, we cannot but express our indignation over the interference in our internal politics. Even then, it is subdued. To hush up the whole scandal would have been impossible and unwise. We would be taken for granted. It would be mistaken as a sign of weakness, a sign of docility. We shall then be abused again. We have to register a point of principle: no foreigners can interfere in our domestic politics. My colleagues and I value our relationships with the US, but we treasure our independence even more.
